H0.text: Nuclear fusion is the process that a collapsing nebula leads to.

H1.text: Nuclear reaction is the process that a collapsing nebula leads to.

H2.text: Destructive fusion is the process that a collapsing nebula leads to.

H3.text: Chemical reaction is the process that a collapsing nebula leads to.

A4.text: When the density and temperature are high enough, deuterium fusion begins, and the outward pressure of the resultant radiation slows (but does not stop) the collapse.

A5.text: Finally, hydrogen begins to fuse in the core of the star, and the rest of the enveloping material is cleared away.

A6.text: The heat from this fusion reaction tends to inflate the protostar, and thereby helps determine the size of the youngest observed pre‑main‑sequence stars.

A7.text: It ends when the infalling gas is depleted, leaving a pre‑main‑sequence star, which contracts to later become a main‑sequence star at the onset of hydrogen fusion producing helium.
